symptoms: shortness of breath, especially upon exertion
pale skin and under the fingernails
manic episodes (euphoria, sudden mood shifts, irritability, agitation)
causes: adverse life events (bereavement, violence, relationship breakdown)
treatment: antidepressants (combined with mood stabilizers during depressive episodes)
lifestyle changes (regular sleep, physical activity, healthy diet)

symptoms: structural anomalies (e.g., heart defects, cleft lip/palate)
causes: alcohol or drug use during pregnancy
treatment: surgery (e.g., for heart defects, cleft lip/palate)

symptoms: Not applicable (this entry focuses on blood transfusion systems, not a disease)

causes: ingestion of botulinum toxin in contaminated food

symptoms: changes in breast size, shape, or appearance
dimpling, redness, or pitting of breast skin
changes in nipple appearance or discharge (may be bloody)
swelling in lymph nodes (underarm or collarbone)
treatment: targeted biological therapy (e.g., trastuzumab for HER2-positive cancer)

causes: consumption of unpasteurized milk or cheese
direct contact with infected animals (farmers, veterinarians)

symptoms: diffuse swelling of limbs or face (oedema)
causes: possible transmission through water or insects
consumption of undercooked poultry or contaminated milk

symptoms: lumps or swelling (e.g., in abdomen, neck)
changes in bowel or bladder habits
vaginal itching and redness (vaginal yeast infection)
pain in arms, shoulder, jaw, or back

causes: transmitted by infected mosquitoes (Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus)
parental stress or mental health issues
consumption of contaminated food or water
contact with infected animal blood or tissues

symptoms: getting lost when walking or driving
being confused, even in familiar places
difficulties solving problems or making decisions
problems following conversations or trouble finding words
feeling anxious, sad, or angry about memory loss
withdrawal from work or social activities
being less interested in other people’s emotions
causes: age (more common in those 65 or older)
treatment: taking part in activities and social interactions that stimulate the brain and maintain daily function
Medicines to control blood pressure and cholesterol

causes: previous infection with DENV increases the risk
treatment: avoid non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, like ibuprofen and aspirin

symptoms: loss of pleasure or interest in activities
feelings of excessive guilt or low self-worth
feeling very tired or low in energy
causes: adverse life events (unemployment, bereavement, traumatic events)
treatment: psychological treatments (behavioral activation, cognitive behavioral therapy, interpersonal psychotherapy, problem-solving therapy)

symptoms: needing to urinate more often than usual
treatment: medications like metformin, sulfonylureas, SGLT-2 inhibitors

symptoms: passage of 3 or more loose or liquid stools per day
severe dehydration (lethargy/unconsciousness, sunken eyes, unable to drink or drink poorly, skin pinch goes back very slowly)
some dehydration (restlessness, irritability, sunken eyes, drinks eagerly, thirsty)
treatment: rehydration with intravenous fluids in case of severe dehydration

symptoms: thick, grey coating in nose, tonsils, and throat

causes: contact with infected animals (fruit bats, chimpanzees, gorillas, monkeys)
direct contact with blood or body fluids of infected persons
treatment: mAb114 (ansuvimabTM) or REGN-EB3 (InmazebTM) for Ebola virus disease

causes: consumption of contaminated foods (raw or undercooked ground meat products, raw milk, contaminated raw vegetables and sprouts)

Symptoms: severe pain in the pelvis, especially during menstrual periods
pain during sex or when using the bathroom
heavy bleeding during periods or between periods
Causes: Stem cells giving rise to the disease
Treatment: Hormonal medicines like GnRH-analogues and contraceptive methods
Surgery to remove lesions, adhesions, and scar tissues

Symptoms: disturbances of movement, sensation, mood, or cognitive functions
higher rates of psychological conditions like anxiety and depression
physical problems such as fractures and bruising
Causes: brain damage from prenatal or perinatal causes
Treatment: surgery for patients who respond poorly to drug treatments

Causes: ingestion of contaminated food and water
direct contact with an infectious person
Treatment: avoiding unnecessary medications that affect the liver

Symptoms: yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice)
Causes: contact with infected blood or body fluids
unsafe injections or exposure to sharp instruments
Treatment: oral medicines like tenofovir or entecavir

symptoms: yellowing of the skin or eyes (jaundice)
causes: Sexual practices leading to blood exposure
treatment: Lifestyle changes (avoiding alcohol, maintaining healthy weight)

causes: Hepatitis D virus (requires Hepatitis B virus for replication)
Consumption of uncooked or undercooked meat
treatment: Avoid unnecessary medications affecting liver function

symptoms: tingling, itching or burning before sores appear

treatment: Lifestyle changes (healthy diet, exercise, weight loss)

symptoms: Fluid in lung cavity (in severe cases)
Bleeding from mouth, nose, vagina or GI tract (in severe cases)
causes: Contact with food/household items contaminated by rodent urine/feces
Direct contact with infected Mastomys rats
treatment: No approved antiviral drug currently available

symptoms: Visceral leishmaniasis: irregular bouts of fever, weight loss, enlargement of the spleen and liver, and anaemia
Cutaneous leishmaniasis: skin lesions, mainly ulcers, on exposed parts of the body, life-long scars, serious disability or stigma
Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis: partial or total destruction of mucous membranes of the nose, mouth and throat
causes: Caused by protozoan parasites transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies
Associated with malnutrition, population displacement, poor housing, weak immune system, lack of financial resources
treatment: Early diagnosis and effective prompt treatment reduce prevalence and prevent disabilities and death
Vector control to reduce or interrupt transmission
Effective disease surveillance to monitor and act during epidemics
Control of animal reservoir hosts tailored to local situation

symptoms: Progressive and permanent disabilities if left untreated
causes: Transmitted via droplets from the nose and mouth during close and frequent contact with untreated cases
treatment: Early diagnosis and prompt treatment can prevent disabilities

symptoms: Noninvasive listeriosis: diarrhoea, fever, headache, muscle pain
Invasive listeriosis: fever, muscle pain, septicemia, meningitis
causes: Transmitted through contaminated food or from pregnant women to unborn babies
treatment: Antibiotics for severe symptoms like meningitis
Prompt administration of antibiotics during pregnancy prevents infection of the fetus or newborn

symptoms: Dull ache or sharp pain between lower edge of ribs and buttock
Pain can radiate into legs, restrict movement, affect sleep, mood, and quality of life
causes: Non-specific LBP (90% of cases): no specific disease or structural reason identified
Specific LBP: caused by underlying disease, tissue damage, or referred from other organs
treatment: Physical therapies to improve muscle strength and mobility
Lifestyle changes: physical activity, healthy diet, good sleep habits
Medicines to reduce symptoms, combined with other treatments

symptoms: Cough that does not go away
Weight loss with no known cause
Lung infections that keep coming back
causes: Exposure to secondhand smoke, occupational hazards (asbestos, radon, certain chemicals), air pollution, hereditary cancer syndromes, chronic lung diseases
treatment: Supportive care for symptom management and quality of life

symptoms: Asymptomatic infections cause hidden damage to lymphatic system
Acute episodes of local inflammation involving skin, lymph nodes, and lymphatic vessels
causes: Caused by infection with nematodes (roundworms) of the family Filariodidea
Transmitted through bites of infected mosquitoes
treatment: Mass drug administration (MDA) with safe medicine combinations
Morbidity management: hygiene, skin care, exercises, elevation of affected limbs

causes: Caused by Plasmodium parasites transmitted through bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes
treatment: Early diagnosis and treatment with antimalarial medicines
Artemisinin-based combination therapy for P. falciparum malaria
Chloroquine for P. vivax in areas where it is still effective
Primaquine to prevent relapses of P. vivax and P. ovale infections

symptoms: Undernutrition: wasting (low weight-for-height), stunting (low height-for-age), underweight (low weight-for-age)
Micronutrient deficiencies: lack of important vitamins and minerals
Overweight, obesity: abnormal or excessive fat accumulation
causes: Deficiencies, excesses, or imbalances in intake of energy and/or nutrients
Poor socioeconomic conditions, inadequate food intake, lack of access to nutritious food
treatment: Promotion of healthy diets and lifestyles

symptoms: High fever, severe headache, severe malaise
Severe watery diarrhoea, abdominal pain, cramping, nausea, vomiting
Haemorrhagic manifestations: fresh blood in vomitus and faeces, bleeding from nose, gums, vagina
causes: Caused by Marburg virus (MARV) and Ravn virus (RAVV)
Transmitted through contact with infected animals (fruit bats) or humans, contaminated materials
treatment: Early intensive supportive care: rehydration, symptomatic treatment
No approved vaccines or antiviral treatments currently available

symptoms: Rash starting on face and upper neck, spreading to hands and feet
causes: Highly contagious, spreads through respiratory droplets or direct contact
treatment: Supportive care: hydration, treatment of symptoms
Vitamin A supplements to prevent eye damage and blindness

causes: Bacterial: Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus agalactiae
treatment: Antibiotic treatment for bacterial meningitis (started immediately)
Supportive care: hydration, pain relief, fever management
Vaccines available for some bacterial causes

causes: Transmitted through close contact with infected persons or animals, contaminated materials
treatment: Supportive care for symptoms: pain and fever management, hydration, skin care
No proven effective antiviral treatment currently available

diseases.name: multi-drug-resistant-gonorrhoea
causes: Resistance to many treatment options including penicillins, sulphonamides, tetracyclines, quinolones, macrolides, and cephalosporins.
Unrestricted access to antimicrobials, inappropriate selection and overuse of antibiotics, and poor quality antibiotics.

diseases.name: multiple-sclerosis
symptoms: Numbness or weakness in the arms and legs
Problems with sexual function or urination
causes: Autoimmune attack on myelin, the fatty insulation that surrounds the nerves in the brain and spinal cord.
treatment: Disease modifying therapies (DMTs) to slow disease progression and prevent relapses.
Steroids for short-term treatment of relapses.
Medicines to reduce symptoms like fatigue, muscle tightening, depression, and urinary or sexual problems.
Rehabilitation to improve functioning and reduce muscle stiffness and spasms.

diseases.name: musculoskeletal-conditions
causes: Pre-existing joint diseases like rheumatoid arthritis or gout.

diseases.name: mycetoma
causes: Traumatic inoculation of fungi or bacteria into the subcutaneous tissue.
treatment: Antifungal drugs and surgery for fungal mycetoma.

diseases.name: mycotoxins
causes: Consumption of food contaminated with mycotoxins produced by certain moulds.

diseases.name: natural-toxins-in-food
symptoms: Acute poisoning ranging from allergic reactions to severe stomachache and diarrhoea.
Long-term effects on the immune, reproductive or nervous systems, and cancer.
causes: Consumption of food containing natural toxins produced by plants, moulds, or other organisms.

diseases.name: newborn-mortality
treatment: Hygienic umbilical cord and skin care.
Assessment for signs of serious health problems.

diseases.name: nipah-virus
symptoms: Atypical pneumonia and severe respiratory problems.
causes: Transmission from animals (bats or pigs) or contaminated foods.
treatment: Intensive supportive care for severe respiratory and neurologic complications.

diseases.name: noma
symptoms: Severe gangrenous disease of the mouth and face.
Soft tissue lesion of the gums progressing to acute necrotizing gingivitis.
causes: Malnutrition, immunosuppression, underlying infections, poor oral health, and extreme poverty.
treatment: Basic hygiene, antibiotics, and improved nutrition for early stages.

diseases.name: obesity-and-overweight
causes: Imbalance of energy intake (diet) and energy expenditure (physical activity).
Obesogenic environments, psycho-social factors, and genetic variants.
treatment: Healthy diet and regular physical activity.
Medicines like non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain control.
Joint replacement surgery for severely affected joints.

diseases.name: opioid-overdose
causes: Overdose of opioids such as heroin, morphine, codeine, fentanyl, methadone, and tramadol.
treatment: Administration of naloxone to reverse the effects of overdose.

diseases.name: oral-health
treatment: Twice-daily tooth brushing with fluoride-containing toothpaste.
Professional dental care for advanced conditions.

diseases.name: oropouche-virus-disease
causes: Bite of infected biting midges or mosquitoes.

diseases.name: osteoarthritis
causes: Pre-existing joint diseases like rheumatoid arthritis or gout.
treatment: Exercise to strengthen muscles and improve mobility.
Joint replacement surgery for severe cases.

causes: Life-threatening illnesses (e.g., cardiovascular diseases, cancer, chronic respiratory diseases, AIDS, diabetes)
Other conditions requiring palliative care (e.g., kidney failure, chronic liver disease, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson’s disease, dementia)
treatment: Team approach to support patients and caregivers
Addressing physical, psychological, social, and spiritual needs
when_to_call_a_doctor: When experiencing severe pain or breathlessness
When needing support for emotional or practical challenges

causes: Exposure to air pollution, pesticides, and solvents
treatment: Rehabilitation (physiotherapy, strength training, gait and balance training, hydrotherapy)
when_to_call_a_doctor: When experiencing worsening motor or non-motor symptoms
When needing adjustments to treatment

causes: System and organizational factors (e.g., inadequate processes, resource constraints)
Technological factors (e.g., issues with health information systems)
External factors (e.g., absence of policies, economic pressures)
treatment: Engaging patients and families in decision-making
when_to_call_a_doctor: When experiencing harm or adverse events in health care
When noticing unsafe practices

symptoms: Chronic health effects (e.g., cancer, adverse reproductive effects)
causes: Exposure to pesticides at work, home, or garden
Consumption of food with pesticide residues
treatment: Washing or peeling fruits and vegetables
when_to_call_a_doctor: When experiencing symptoms of poisoning
When exposed to large quantities of pesticides

symptoms: Increased risk of noncommunicable diseases (e.g., cardiovascular diseases, cancer, diabetes)
treatment: Regular physical activity (e.g., walking, cycling, sports)
when_to_call_a_doctor: When experiencing health issues due to inactivity
When needing guidance on exercise routines

symptoms: Open sores filled with pus (in advanced stages)
when_to_call_a_doctor: When experiencing symptoms after exposure to plague
When in contact with infected animals or fleas

causes: Respiratory syncytial virus (most common viral cause)
when_to_call_a_doctor: When a child has cough or difficulty breathing
When symptoms worsen or persist

symptoms: Burning sensation and itching on the back of the feet
Papillomatous growths around the feet and heel
causes: Long-term exposure of bare feet to irritant soils
treatment: Use of shoes to reduce exposure to irritant soil
when_to_call_a_doctor: When noticing early signs of leg swelling
When experiencing acute attacks or infections

causes: Person-to-person spread through faecal-oral route or contaminated water/food
treatment: No cure, only prevention through vaccination
when_to_call_a_doctor: When experiencing symptoms of polio
When exposed to someone with polio

symptoms: Excessive hair on the face or body
Weight gain, especially around the belly
causes: Family history of PCOS or type 2 diabetes
treatment: Medicines for acne or unwanted hair growth
when_to_call_a_doctor: When experiencing irregular periods or infertility
When needing management for symptoms like acne or hair growth

symptoms: Aches and pains in muscles or joints
causes: Persistence of virus in the body
when_to_call_a_doctor: When symptoms persist or worsen after COVID-19
When experiencing severe or debilitating symptoms

symptoms: Re-experiencing the traumatic event (e.g., intrusive memories, nightmares, flashbacks)
Avoidance of reminders of the event
causes: Exposure to potentially traumatic events (e.g., war, accidents, natural disasters, sexual violence)
Family history of mental health conditions
treatment: Cognitive behavioural therapy with a trauma focus
when_to_call_a_doctor: When experiencing distressing symptoms after a traumatic event
When symptoms interfere with daily life

symptoms: Visual disturbances (e.g., blurred vision, seeing spots)
Nausea and vomiting (after the first trimester)
Swelling in the hands and face
causes: Pre-existing conditions (e.g., hypertension, diabetes, kidney disease)
treatment: Close monitoring of maternal and fetal health
when_to_call_a_doctor: When experiencing symptoms during pregnancy
When blood pressure readings are high

symptoms: Complications in newborns (e.g., respiratory distress, infections)
treatment: Antibiotics for preterm prolabour rupture of membranes (PPROM)
when_to_call_a_doctor: When signs of preterm labour occur
When experiencing pregnancy complications

symptoms: Tingling or burning at the wound site
causes: Bite or scratch from an infected animal (e.g., dog)
treatment: Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP): thorough wound washing, rabies vaccine, rabies immunoglobulins (RIG)
when_to_call_a_doctor: Immediately after a bite or scratch from a potentially rabid animal
When experiencing symptoms of rabies

symptoms: Worse health outcomes due to barriers (e.g., language, discrimination)
Poor mental health (e.g., anxiety, depression, PTSD)
causes: Experiences in country of origin (e.g., war, conflict, natural disasters)
Living and working conditions in host country
when_to_call_a_doctor: When experiencing health issues due to migration
When needing access to health services

causes: host country’s entry and integration policies
treatment: culturally sensitive and integrated mental health care

symptoms: difficulty with thinking, seeing, hearing, communicating, eating, or moving around
swelling of stomach, hands or feet
causes: immune system reaction causing inflammation and scarring of heart valves
treatment: surgery to replace or repair damaged valves
medication for heart failure or heart rhythm abnormalities

causes: risk factors include smoking, obesity, exposure to air pollution
contact with blood or organs of infected animals
treatment: no specific treatment for mild cases

causes: direct contact with infected person or animal
indirect contact with contaminated objects or surfaces
environmental contact with fungi in soil
treatment: topical antifungal medications (clotrimazole, miconazole, econazole, ciclopirox, terbinafine)

causes: driving under influence of alcohol or drugs
consumption of contaminated food of animal origin
exposure to airborne mineral dust particles

symptoms: enflamed bumps on male genitalia and female breasts
rash in infants and small children
causes: parasitic infestation by Sarcoptes scabiei var hominis
treatment: topical medications (5% permethrin cream, 0.5% malathion, 10–25% benzyl benzoate emulsion, 5–10% sulphur ointment)
antiseptics or antibiotics for bacterial infections

causes: interaction between genes and environmental factors
viral infections (hepatitis B, herpes simplex virus, HIV, human papillomavirus)

when_to_call_a_doctor: if rash appears near the eye
if pain is severe
if symptoms persist or worsen

symptoms: bleeding disorders leading to fatal haemorrhage
tissue damage causing permanent disability and limb amputation
treatment: included in WHO List of essential medicines
manage climate change and digital transformation
use herbs and spices instead of salt

causes: infection by parasitic worms (roundworm, whipworm, hookworm)

symptoms: partial or complete loss of sensory and/or motor functions
dysregulation of blood pressure, heart rate, and/or body temperature
nodules and plaques on exposed skin sites
arthritis, respiratory infection, meningitis (rare deep forms)
causes: contact with contaminated plant materials or infected cats

symptoms: harmful effects due to contaminants or toxic substances
treatment: access to safe, affordable medical products

causes: bacterial metabolism of sugars producing acid

symptoms: breakdown in ability to deal with life stresses
conflict, disaster, violence, abuse, or loss
causes: multi-faceted: social, cultural, biological, psychological, environmental factors
treatment: limit access to means of suicide
early identification and management of suicidal behaviors

symptoms: tertiary stage: brain and cardiovascular diseases
congenital syphilis: rashes, inflammation, anaemia, developmental delays
neurocysticercosis: severe headache, blindness, convulsions, epileptic seizures
causes: ingestion of eggs via fecal-oral route

symptoms: jaw cramping or inability to open mouth
changes in blood pressure or heart rate

causes: transmission via eye and nose discharges

symptoms: itch, pain when urinating, pain during intercourse (in women)
urethral discharge or pain when urinating (in men)
first stage: bouts of fever, headache, enlarged lymph nodes, joint pains, itching
second stage: behavior changes, confusion, sensory disturbances, poor coordination, sleep cycle disturbance
treatment: fexinidazole (first and non-severe second stage, gambiense-HAT)

causes: spreads through the air when infected people cough, sneeze, or spit
treatment: treatment for drug-resistant TB requires different medicines
when_to_call_a_doctor: if symptoms like prolonged cough, fever, and unexplained weight loss persist
if at increased risk (e.g., HIV infection, contact with TB patients)

symptoms: lesions on feet (whitish disc with dark center)
causes: infection by female sand flea (Tunga penetrans)
transmission from contaminated soil or floors
treatment: wound care and tetanus vaccination if needed
when_to_call_a_doctor: if lesions show signs of infection (e.g., abscesses, swelling)
if experiencing severe pain or difficulty walking
if symptoms like high fever and abdominal pain occur
after travel to endemic areas with poor sanitation

symptoms: skin cancer (melanoma, squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma)
causes: exposure to UV radiation from the sun or artificial sources
when_to_call_a_doctor: if unusual skin changes or growths appear
if vision problems develop

causes: West Nile virus transmitted by mosquito bites
when_to_call_a_doctor: if neurological symptoms develop (e.g., confusion, muscle weakness)
after mosquito bites in endemic areas

causes: Zika virus transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes
treatment: pain and fever relief (avoid NSAIDs until dengue is ruled out)
when_to_call_a_doctor: if pregnant and exposed to Zika virus
if symptoms of Guillain-Barré syndrome develop (e.g., muscle weakness)
